articles.author: Austin Frakt
articles.description:
If you subscribe to TIE by email (which you can do here), a big change is coming, but you shouldn’t be concerned. Here are the details: Heretofore, you received your TIE emails of posts via feedburner, which Google is discontinuing at the end of the month. Therefore, henceforth, you will receive TIE emails via MailChimp. […]
Change coming for email subscribers first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Change coming for email subscribers

articles.author: Bill Gardner
articles.description:
I’m fortunate to work for a hospital that provides excellent disability benefits (even in Canada, not all employers do). To qualify, I needed to get a form completed by my oncologist. Before I returned it to Human Resources, I read it. There it is, concise and direct: “Incurable cancer.” The editor in me loves it, […]
Cancer Journal: Citizenship in the Kingdom of Malady first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Cancer Journal: Citizenship in the Kingdom of Malady

articles.author: Tiffany Doherty
articles.description:
Last week we covered CBD and mental health, finding that data to back up health claims are scarce and that consumer CBD products are often sketchy. In this week’s episode on CBD and other health ailments, we find that many of the same caveats apply.   @DrTiff_PhD
Does CBD Have Any Value as a Treatment? first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Does CBD Have Any Value as a Treatment?

articles.author: Tiffany Doherty
articles.description:
Cannabidiol, or CBD, is one of the most well-known components of marijuana and is not psychoactive like its THC counterpart. It has been touted as a treatment for almost any mental health   condition you can think of, but the overall evidence for this in humans is pretty scant. Beyond that, the evidence we do have […]
Test post #2: CBD and Mental Health first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Test post #2: CBD and Mental Health

articles.author: guest contributor
articles.description:
This is a guest post by Will Raderman (@RadWill_), Alexandra Skinner (@alexskinnermph), and Julia Raifman (@JuliaRaifman). Will Raderman is a research fellow at Boston University School of Public Health. Alexandra Skinner is a research fellow at Boston University School of Public Health. Julia Raifman is an Assistant Professor at Boston University School of Public Health. […]
Permanent expansions of government data collection will support policy innovation first appeared on The Incidental Economist.
articles.title: Permanent expansions of government data collection will support policy innovation

articles.author: PS editors
articles.title: PS Events: Back to Health

articles.author: Jeffrey D. Sachs
articles.description: As recent disasters have shown, the world’s small island developing states are acutely vulnerable to the ravages of climate change, a problem created almost entirely by rich countries. If the international community is serious about sustainable development that leaves no one behind, rich countries must do three things.
articles.title: The Rich World’s Debt to Island States

articles.author: Kemal Derviş
articles.description: As policymakers prepare for the crucial COP26 climate summit in November, prospects for achieving a carbon-neutral world by 2050 are improving. But it is unrealistic to expect to keep global warming well below 2° Celsius if middle- and lower-middle-income countries do not participate fully in the green transformation.
articles.title: The Key to Global Climate Success

articles.author: Bill McKibben
articles.description: By any moral calculation, the United States should be weighing its responsibilities to Central Americans displaced by climate disasters. And, whether migrants cross international borders or not, it should be US policy to make their journeys as safe and humane as possible.
articles.title: Our Responsibility to Climate Migrants

articles.author: Paul Milgrom
articles.description: Misallocation of scarce resources too often deprives users of them even as others waste their supply. Well-designed markets can overcome such problems by enabling voluntary transactions that allow existing users to retain their allotments while enabling higher-value uses.
articles.title: The Power of Market Design

articles.author: PS Commentators
articles.description: The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic means that the upcoming Summer Olympic and Paralympic Games in the Japanese capital, originally scheduled to take place in 2020, will be unlike any before. What is not new is that many are asking whether the spectacle is worth the cost.
articles.title: Tokyo’s COVID Games

articles.author: Cory Doctorow
articles.description: From the European Union to China, authorities are cracking down on large tech companies. But to protect individual digital rights and break the monopoly power that is destroying our societies, much more needs to be done.
articles.title: Reset the Internet?

articles.author: Mark Leonard
articles.description: Although Germany remains indispensable to European unity and solidarity, new polling shows that German citizens have begun to sour on the European project during the COVID-19 pandemic. If German politicians do not revise how they talk about Europe, this change of sentiment could have disastrous long-term consequences.
articles.title: Germany’s Patriotism Paradox

articles.author: Anders Åslund
articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin has lately been going to great lengths to highlight the historical linkages between his country and Ukraine. In denying that Ukraine has any right to independence, Putin is setting the stage for war.
articles.title: Putin’s Dangerous Ukraine Narrative

articles.author: Otaviano Canuto
articles.description: Market movements this month have led to renewed fears that changes in US financial and monetary conditions will trigger a painful wave of capital flight from emerging markets, as happened in 2013. But times have changed, and the greatest risks to emerging markets now lie elsewhere.
articles.title: Will Another Taper Tantrum Hit Emerging Markets?

articles.author: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala
articles.description: For years, WTO members have failed to forge an agreement to limit fishing subsidies, thereby allowing the continuation of ecologically devastating fishing operations that would otherwise be economically unviable. But with another round of negotiations this month, they have a chance to make up for lost time.
articles.title: A Golden Opportunity to End Destructive Fishing Subsidies

articles.author: Takatoshi Ito
articles.description: Japan's new state of emergency declaration in response to COVID-19 concerns has eliminated any remaining hope for a “normal” Olympic/Paralympic Games in Tokyo this summer. Whether it will also bear on Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's political prospects this fall remains to be seen.
articles.title: Japan’s Quiet Olympics

articles.author: Brahma Chellaney
articles.description: Former US Secretary of Defense Robert Gates wrote in 2014 that Joe Biden “has been wrong on nearly every major foreign-policy and national-security issue over the past four decades.” The hasty US withdrawal from Afghanistan is set to extend that pattern.
articles.title: Biden’s Afghan Blunder

articles.author: Barry Eichengreen
articles.description: An obscure corner of the digital sphere that was poorly understood two years ago is now subject to increasingly intense scrutiny by central bankers, regulators, and investors. Unfortunately, more intense scrutiny has not necessarily meant better understanding.
articles.title: The Stablecoin Illusion

articles.author: Werner Hoyer
articles.description: Although Africa still suffers some of the highest poverty rates in the world, the continent overall has massive potential to achieve broad-based, sustainable growth this century. International financial institutions must listen to forward-looking African leaders and adapt their investment strategies accordingly.
articles.title: Deepening the EU-African Partnership

articles.author: Mary Robinson
articles.description: The world will neither rebuild from the pandemic, nor have any chance of tackling wider existential threats such as climate change, until leaders once more instill a sense of hope in political and civic life. Fortunately, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights offers a roadmap to help humanity chart a path forward.
articles.title: A Human-Rights Approach to Global Challenges

articles.author: Hilal Elver
articles.description: The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the fragility and inequity of globalized industrial food systems. Transforming them will require leaders to prioritize the vulnerable over the powerful, enhance resilience, establish transparent value chains, and provide everyone with affordable access to the foods needed for a healthy diet.
articles.title: The Global Food System Isn’t Working

articles.author: Bernard Haykel
articles.description: This week in Say More, PS talks with Bernard Haykel, Professor of Near Eastern Studies and Director of the Institute for the Transregional Study of the Contemporary Middle East, North Africa, and Central Asia at Princeton University.
articles.title: An Interview with Bernard Haykel

articles.author: Daniel Gros
articles.description: Different economic conditions and priorities in the US and the eurozone are leading to divergent macroeconomic-policy approaches. While there is nothing shocking about this, there are potential longer-term effects that should not be underestimated.
articles.title: The Transatlantic Macroeconomic Divergence

articles.author: Minxin Pei
articles.description: The Communist Party of China’s crackdown on ride-hailing firm Didi over supposed data-security concerns seems to be just the beginning of a wider campaign to assert control over the country’s thriving tech sector. Foreign investors hoping that Chinese leaders will realize their folly and reverse course should think again.
articles.title: China Is Killing Its Tech Golden Goose

articles.author: Joseph E. Stiglitz
articles.description: By siding with major food corporations over six Malian former child slaves who were seeking compensation under US tort laws, the US Supreme Court has sent a dangerous message. Apparently, US corporations will not be held to the same standards of decency and human rights abroad as they are at home.
articles.title: Are US Corporations Above the Law?

articles.author: Jayati Ghosh
articles.description: There is no magic bullet that can ensure emerging Asian economies actually emerge and live up to their huge promise. But, given the marked economic slowdown that hit key countries well before the pandemic, a radical reconsideration of capital-account management would be a good place to start.
articles.title: Where Have All the Asian Tigers Gone?

articles.author: Sigmar Gabriel
articles.description: In seeking to renew the image of liberal democracy in an age of rising authoritarianism, US President Joe Biden recognizes that the first step is for the West to get its own house in order. For Europe, that means finally overcoming longstanding political hurdles to deeper economic integration.
articles.title: Will Europe Rise to Biden’s Challenge?

articles.author: Shang-Jin Wei
articles.description: At-risk economies may have six months or so to implement self-help measures before any sudden US monetary-policy tightening happens. They are well advised to work on making their exchange rates more flexible, reducing their reliance on foreign-currency debt, and increasing their foreign-exchange reserves.
articles.title: The Global Dangers of Rising US Inflation

articles.author: Michael R. Bloomberg
articles.description: Abundance in a zero-emissions world means no longer exploiting and wasting finite resources, but rather valuing the nature that sustains and protects us. And three upcoming United Nations summits give governments the opportunity to listen to a chorus of calls for a healthier, more resilient future.
articles.title: The Race to Sustainable Abundance

articles.author: Nancy Qian
articles.description: For decades, development aid has gone either to governments that lack the ability to administer it, or to non-government actors who essentially compete with the state. It is time for a new approach centered on a less ambitious but far more practical objective.
articles.title: What Should Development Aid Do?

articles.author: Amal de Chickera
articles.description: Today, an estimated 15 million people are stateless, and tens of millions more are at risk of losing their nationality. This leads to exclusion and deprivation in every facet of life – with consequences that have become even more dire during the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.title: Statelessness in a Pandemic

articles.author: Muhammad Yunus
articles.description: With so much of “normal” social and economic life put on hold by the coronavirus pandemic, there is no better time to consider new approaches to development. Until we have achieved environmental, social, and economic sustainability, we as a species will be racing against the clock.
articles.title: The Pandemic Opportunity

articles.author: Peter Singer
articles.description: The way that livestock is raised and killed has long made it a legitimate matter of public concern. Now that we can see that eating red meat affects the entire planet in a manner that none of us want, it is time for governments to end their support for it.
articles.title: Beefatarians Not Wanted

articles.author: Anu Madgavkar
articles.description: The behavioral changes that persist after the pandemic will offer new business opportunities for firms that carefully assess consumer, industry, and regulatory trends. And policymakers can help the world to boost productivity by extending and improving digital infrastructure and ensuring universal access to it.
articles.title: The Stickiness of Pandemic-Driven Economic Behavior

articles.author: Nancy Qian
articles.title: Back to Health: Nancy Qian

articles.author: Ilona Szabó
articles.description: Although the COVID-19 pandemic has raised our awareness of other environmental threats like climate change, the destruction of the Amazon, one of the planet's most important climate stabilizers, continues to accelerate. Reversing this dangerous trend will require urgent reforms, underpinned by an entirely new mindset.
articles.title: Where Humanity’s Future Will Be Decided

articles.author: David Miliband
articles.title: Back to Health: David Miliband

articles.author: Bill Emmott
articles.description: A growing chorus is calling for the long-awaited Tokyo Olympics to be canceled, even though the facts on the ground leave Japanese authorities with no sound reason to do so. The only thing that will stop the event now is a no-show by all of the athletes themselves.
articles.title: The Tokyo Games Will Go on

articles.author: Carl Manlan
articles.title: Back to Health: Carl Manlan

articles.author: Werner Hoyer
articles.title: Back to Health: Werner Hoyer

articles.author: Julia Gillard
articles.title: Back to Health: Julia Gillard

articles.author: Nicole Pope
articles.description: While media capture occurs in the best of times, a crisis creates opportunities to act even more brazenly to assert control over the information to which people are exposed. During the coronavirus pandemic, both repressive governments and Big Tech behemoths have seized these opportunities.
articles.title: Media Capture Under Cover of COVID

articles.author: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
articles.title: Back to Health: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

articles.author: Ed Araral
articles.description: Given the current trajectory of climate change, it is crucial that initial steps by the United States and the European Union to introduce carbon border taxes are successful. That will require policymakers to adhere to the essential principles that should govern such levies.
articles.title: The Case for Carbon Import Taxes

articles.author: Dani Rodrik
articles.description: Just as the pandemic was gathering pace in early 2020, French President Emmanuel Macron set up an international commission of economists to assess longer-term challenges and make policy proposals. While some of the recommendations are specific to France, many (if not most) are relevant to other advanced economies as well.
articles.title: Inequality and the Macron Commission

articles.author: Tom Frieden
articles.title: Back to Health: Tom Frieden

articles.author: PS Commentators
articles.description: As US and NATO troops prepare to leave Afghanistan by mid-July and the Taliban make rapid territorial gains, the outlook for the country’s long-suffering people is becoming bleaker by the day. The withdrawal is also likely to undermine regional security, embolden Islamist militants, and damage America’s already shaky international standing.
articles.title: Afghanistan on the Brink

articles.author: Sally C. Davies
articles.title: Back to Health: Sally C. Davies

articles.author: Gro Harlem Brundtland
articles.title: Back to Health: Gro Harlem Brundtland

articles.author: Vera Songwe
articles.description: If Africa emerges from COVID-19 with old inequalities unaddressed and new opportunities unrealized, its policymakers will have failed. If they recognize that a better normal is possible, and act boldly to make it a reality, the continent will at least have something to show for the suffering of the past year.
articles.title: A Better Normal for Africa

articles.author: Koketso Moeti
articles.description: Societies must address the distribution of political and economic power that drives efforts to use digital technologies for repressive ends. Otherwise, governments and corporations will continue to diminish digital citizenship to enhance their own powers or advance their private interests.
articles.title: The Battle for Civic Space in the Digital Age

articles.author: Sławomir Sierakowski
articles.description: By reclaiming the leadership of Poland's liberal center-right party, former European Council President Donald Tusk has shaken up the Polish political scene and cast a shadow over some of its younger rising stars. To succeed, he will need to show that the Brussels technocracy didn't rub off on him.
articles.title: Donald Tusk Comes Home

articles.author: Mark Malloch-Brown
articles.description: For decades, democracy and human-rights advocates have operated on the assumption that a growing number of governments around the world were embracing freedom and its rules and norms. But the recent sharp reversal of a generation of progress is forcing advocates and activists to reconsider their models of change.
articles.title: The Fight for Open Societies Begins Again

articles.author: Agnes Binagwaho
articles.title: Back to Health: Agnes Binagwaho

articles.author: Seth Berkley
articles.title: Back to Health: Seth Berkley

articles.author: Ann Aerts
articles.title: Back to Health: Ann Aerts

articles.author: Jeffrey D. Sachs
articles.description: It is imperative that the G20 finance ministers' meeting in Venice this week act to provide the COVID-19 vaccines needed to achieve worldwide comprehensive adult immunization by early 2022. Given current production, this should not be a problem, so long as a global plan is quickly implemented.
articles.title: The G20 Must Act Now to Vaccinate the World

articles.author: Joseph S. Nye, Jr.
articles.description: Even if formal cybersecurity treaties are unworkable, it may still be possible to set limits on certain types of civilian targets, and to negotiate rough rules of the road. Whether US President Joe Biden succeeded in launching such a process at his meeting last month with Russian President Vladimir Putin may become clear soon.
articles.title: What Did Biden Achieve in Geneva?

articles.author: Christopher J.L. Murray
articles.description: The COVID-19 crisis is far from over; in many countries, it is getting worse. By investing in digital technologies now and publishing anonymized data online, policymakers can strengthen their response to the ongoing pandemic, and act quickly when another public-health threat appears.
articles.title: The Public-Health Data Systems We Need

articles.author: José Antonio Ocampo
articles.description: The recent agreement by 131 countries to reform international corporate taxation is not the end of the road. But to bring about a more equitable outcome, developing countries must now push for a higher global minimum tax rate and a bigger reallocation of taxing rights, and refuse mandatory arbitration.
articles.title: How to Secure a Fairer Global Tax Deal

articles.author: Swee Kheng Khor
articles.description: The post-pandemic rebuilding period must feature ambitious investments in the physical, organizational, and social infrastructure needed to ensure universal health coverage. Governments have a historic opportunity to place health at the center of all policymaking, where it belongs.
articles.title: A Health New Deal

articles.author: Daron Acemoglu
articles.description: While the risk of sustained US inflation should not be ignored, nor should it cloud our view of what is really at stake in the current post-pandemic economy. American democracy is in trouble, and a robust, inclusive government-led recovery may offer the last best chance of putting it on a sounder footing.
articles.title: The Real Inflation Risk

articles.author: Djoomart Otorbaev
articles.description: With US and NATO troops on their way out and the Taliban making rapid territorial gains, Russia, China, and Central Asian governments are increasingly worried about what a destabilized Afghanistan will mean for the wider region. While all hope is not lost, the outlook is becoming bleaker by the day.
articles.title: If Afghanistan Falls

articles.author: Muhammad Hamid Zaman
articles.description: Now that COVID-19 has illustrated the destruction that can be wrought by a single virus, there is no longer any excuse for delay in tackling the growing threat posed by antimicrobial resistance. There is still time to prevent a worst-case scenario, but the window is closing fast.
articles.title: Learning from COVID to Fight Drug-Resistant Disease

articles.author: Mohamed A. El-Erian
articles.description: As the global economy emerges from the COVID-19 shock, systemically important central banks are faced with the unenviable task of deciding when and how quickly to phase out extraordinary stimulus measures. While there is no easy answer, there are clear criteria for maintaining policy credibility.
articles.title: Central Banking, Fast and Slow

articles.author: Rana Mitter
articles.description: The Communist Party of China, founded a century ago, has been in power for more than seven decades – and it has big plans for the future. What do those plans entail, and is the Party still strong enough to implement them?
articles.title: The Communist Party of China at 100

articles.author: Melvyn B. Krauss
articles.description: Notwithstanding the predictable howls of protest from some Europeans, US President Joe Biden, French President Emmanuel Macron, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel are right to seek a thawing of ties with Russian President Vladimir Putin. If the main global threat is China, Putin has several compelling reasons to play ball.
articles.title: Joe Biden’s Nixon Strategy

articles.author: Joseph E. Stiglitz
articles.description: Under existing tax rules, multinational firms can escape paying their fair share of taxes by booking their income in low-tax jurisdictions, or by moving some parts of their business to these jurisdictions. Will proposed reforms deliver on their promise to boost government revenues, especially in developing countries?
articles.title: The Global Tax Devil Is in the Details

articles.author: Ludovic Subran
articles.description: What European households do with the cash buffers they have built up during the pandemic could have good, bad, or ugly consequences. The best option is for policymakers to help channel these savings into long-term investments that support the continent’s green and digital transformations.
articles.title: How to Use Europe’s Excess Savings

articles.author: Mari Pangestu
articles.description: Nowadays, advocates of protectionism increasingly base their arguments on trade’s adverse distributional consequences. But governments must remember that the potential benefits of trade are far greater, provided they can put in place policies that deliver them more equitably.
articles.title: Making Trade Work for Everyone

sources.title: Handelsblatt Online - Wirtschaft - Politik, Unternehmen und Finanzen

articles.description: Der Covid-Impfstoffhersteller hat im vergangenen Jahr Kurszuwächse von 150 Prozent verzeichnet. Nun soll das Papier im S&P-Index gelistet werden.
articles.title: Impfstoffhersteller: US-Biotechunternehmen Moderna zieht in den S&P-500-Index ein

articles.title: Janet Yellen: US-Finanzministerin: Vielleicht muss Amazon keine Mindeststeuer zahlen

articles.title: Gemeinsame Pressekonferenz mit Biden und Merkel: USA und Deutschland beschließen Energie- und Klimapartnerschaft – Entscheidung über EU-Travel-Ban könnte bald fallen

articles.title: Landtag: Sachsen-Anhalt: CDU und FDP für schwarz-rot-gelbe Verhandlungen

articles.description: Am Freitag spricht Fed-Chef Powell mit US-Finanzministerin Janet Yellen über die Risiken der steigenden Preise. Wie heiß ist der Markt weltweit gelaufen?
articles.title: Marktüberblick: Wohnungsverkäufe binnen Minuten: Sorgen vor weltweiter Immobilienblase nehmen zu

articles.description: Johnson sieht Großbritannien „auf gutem Weg aus der Pandemie“ +++ Spahn fordert umfassendere Untersuchung in China +++ Slowakei beharrt auf Quarantänepflicht für Ungeimpfte +++ Der Newsblog.
articles.title: +++ Corona-News +++: Balearen melden so viele Neuinfektionen wie nie zuvor – WHO-Chef nennt Ablehnung der Labor-Theorie vorschnell

articles.description: Mit der geplanten Einführung eines CO2-Zolls riskiert die EU einen Handelskrieg. Doch inzwischen erwägen die USA ein ähnliches Konzept. Gelingt es, eine Eskalation zu verhindern?
articles.title: Handelspolitik: Was kostet der Ausstoß von Treibhausgasen? Der schwere Weg zum Klimapakt

articles.description: Südafrika driftet ab in einem Mix aus Kriminalität, wirtschaftlicher Not und politischer Hoffnungslosigkeit. Die Fehler der vergangenen 25 Jahre rächen sich jetzt.
articles.title: Unruhen: Brennende Supermärkte, zerstörte Unternehmen: Südafrika versinkt in Gewalt

articles.description: Mithilfe einer bereits börsennotierten Firmenhülle wagt sich das von Amazon unterstütze Unternehmen aufs Parkett. Dabei will es rund zwei Milliarden Dollar einnehmen.
articles.title: Start-up: Roboterauto-Firma Aurora geht an die Börse

articles.description: Russland darf nicht unbegrenzt Gas durch die Ostsee nach Deutschland liefern. Es geht um eine Verlängerung der ersten Nord-Stream-Pipeline – es könnte aber auch Nord Stream 2 betroffen sein.
articles.title: Urteil: Deutschland unterliegt am EuGH im Streit über russisches Gas

articles.description: Lieferando-Eigner rechnet 2021 mit mehr Bestellungen +++ Suse-Gewinn fällt leicht +++ Online-Modehändler Asos steigert Umsatz +++  Die Geschäftszahlen des Tages.
articles.title: +++ Geschäftszahlen im Newsblog +++: Jenoptik erhöht Prognose nach Gewinnsprung – Finanzinvestor Partners Group hebt Wachstumsprognose an

articles.description: Etwa 20000 ausländische Kämpfer sollen noch in Libyen sein. Lange Zeit liefen die Bemühungen um einen Rückzug ins Leere. Das soll sich nun ändern.
articles.title: Rückzug: Maas erwartet baldigen Beginn des Truppenabzugs aus Libyen

articles.description: Nach dem Rekord am Mittwoch ist der Dax am Donnerstag deutlich abgerutscht. Doch ein Blick auf das Verhalten der Anleger zeigt: Eine größere Sommerkorrektur dürfte es vorerst nicht geben.
articles.title: Dax aktuell: Dax schließt 160 Punkte im Minus – Heimische Anlageprofis wollen jetzt mit fallenden Kursen Geld verdienen

articles.description: LGT aus Liechtenstein steigt mit signifikantem Minderheitsanteil bei Berliner Fintech ein.
articles.title: Asset-Management: Online-Vermögensverwalter Liqid gewinnt Privatbank LGT als Großinvestor

articles.description: Der Chef der US-Notenbank hat am Donnerstag eingeräumt, von der starken Inflation überrascht worden zu sein. Er hält jedoch weiter an der Ansicht fest, dass sie nur vorübergehend ist.
articles.title: Geldpolitik: Fed-Chef Powell hatte nicht mit so starkem Inflationsanstieg gerechnet

articles.description: Das Interesse an Kryptowährungen ist abgeflacht. Bitcoin-Kurs pendelt zwischen 30.000 und 40.000 Dollar. Alles Neue zu Bitcoin und Co. im Newsblog.
articles.title: Bitcoin, Ether und Dogecoin: Handelsvolumen beim Bitcoin auf dem niedrigsten Stand seit acht Monaten

articles.description: Das EU-Klimaprogramm erhöht den Druck auf deutsche Industriebetriebe. Sie fürchten nun, dass Konkurrenten im Ausland bald günstiger produzieren können.
articles.title: Standort Deutschland: Mittelstand ächzt unter Klimazielen: „Dann rutschen wir in die roten Zahlen“

articles.description: Das Sturmtief „Bernd“ zeigt einmal mehr, wie unberechenbar Umweltgefahren für Leben, aber auch Hab und Gut sind. Wie sich Menschen materiell absichern können.
articles.title: Hauseigentümer, Mieter, Autofahrer: Policen für Unwetter, Sturm und Starkregen: Sieben Fehler, die Versicherte vermeiden sollten

articles.description: Als letzte der großen US-Banken meldete Morgan Stanley einen Gewinnsprung. Trotz der positiven Quartalszahlen realisierten Anleger lieber Gewinne.
articles.title: Dow Jones, Nasdaq, S&P 500: Wall Street schließt uneinheitlich – Aktie der Kinokette AMC stoppt den Kursverfall

articles.description: Die Supermarktketten der Schwarz-Gruppe haben von den Kaufgewohnheiten während Corona profitiert. Allgemein sind die Discounter weniger stark gewachsen.
articles.title: Discounter: Führungskrise bremst Wachstum bei Lidl und Kaufland nicht

articles.description: Die operative Umsatzrendite von Siemens Energie wird wohl unterhalb der angepeilten Spanne liegen. Grund sind auch Probleme beim Anlagenbauer Gamesa.
articles.title: Windkraft-Tochter: Siemens Energy verfehlt wegen Gamesa Gewinnprognose

articles.description: Der Kaufpreis der Lebensversicherungssparte betrage 2,2 Milliarden Dollar. Die Sparte hatte für Verbraucher zuletzt an Attraktivität verloren.
articles.title: Versicherer: AIG verkauft Anteil an seiner Leben-Sparte an Blackrock

articles.description: Tief „Bernd“ sorgt für Ausnahmezustände in einigen Regionen Deutschlands. Besonders schwer traf es unter anderem Düsseldorf und Hagen. In Wuppertal droht die Wupper-Talsperre überzulaufen.
articles.title: Unwetter in Deutschland: Bahnverkehr in NRW nach Starkregen auf zahlreichen Linien eingestellt – Vulkaneifel ruft Katastrophenfall aus

articles.description: Traton erreicht Niveau vor der Krise +++ Hugo Boss steigert Umsatz und Ergebnis deutlich +++ Delta Air mit erstem Quartalsgewinn seit Pandemiebeginn  +++ Die Geschäftszahlen des Tages.
articles.title: +++ Geschäftszahlen im Newsblog +++: Drägerwerk wegen hoher Kosten mit Gewinnrückgang – Siemens Gamesa befürchtet 2020/21 wieder Verlust

articles.description: Die Mehrheit der Amerikaner sieht China einer Studie zufolge als Risiko, in Deutschland ist das nicht der Fall. Dennoch gibt es Chancen für eine engere Zusammenarbeit in der Chinapolitik.
articles.title: Studie : Gemeinsam gegen Peking: Wie eine transatlantische Chinapolitik aussehen könnte

articles.description: Die genossenschaftlichen PSD-Banken gelten als Vorreiter bei der Online-Baufinanzierung. Beobachter gehen davon aus, dass die Entwicklung Auswirkungen auf die Filialen hat.
